content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata xml:lang="en"><Esri><MetaID>{F42124E7-95AB-4E4D-A3B5-46DBE4116007}</MetaID><CreaDate>20070108</CreaDate><CreaTime>11440900</CreaTime><SyncOnce>FALSE</SyncOnce><SyncDate>20110727</SyncDate><SyncTime>15150200</SyncTime><ModDate>20110727</ModDate><ModTime>15192700</ModTime></Esri><idinfo><native Sync="TRUE">Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.0.1770</native><descript><langdata Sync="TRUE">en</langdata><abstract>The California Pesticide Use Report data contains very detailed information across space and time.  It is summarized by the following categories: 1) Individual pesticide chemical or groups of chemicals or all chemicals 2) Individual application site(crop) or group of sites(crops) or all sites(crops) 3) Individual county or all counties 4) Multiple years start from year 1991 to year 2009, and it is continuously updated 5) Measures of pesticide usage by Gross Pounds, or pesticide application intensity by Application Rate (Pounds per Acre Treated), or by Acre Treated.</abstract><purpose>The California pesticide usage data for Township range is prepared for Agricultural Pesticide Web Mapping Service(WMS) (See http://www.ehib.org/tool.jsp?tool_key=18).</purpose><supplinf>Pesticide use data is provided by the Department of Pesticide Regulation (DPR) Pesticide Use Reports. </supplinf></descript><citation><citeinfo><origin>California Department of Pesticide Regulation (DPR) </origin><pubdate>Year 2009 and it will be continuously updated</pubdate><title>California Annual Pesticide Use Summary Data by County, Township, and Section, 1991-2009</title><ftname Sync="TRUE">BASEDATA.SDE.PUR_TOWNSHIP_VIEW</ftname><geoform Sync="TRUE">vector digital Prior to March 23, 2009, application rate and acres treated values were erroneously displaying values that didn't take into account units for some applications that might be in square feet. </cntorg></cntperp><cntpos>IT / GIS Specialist </cntpos><cntvoice>(510) 620-3664 </cntvoice><cntfax>(510) 620-3720 </cntfax><cntemail>liang.guo@cdph.ca.gov</cntemail><cntinst>Preferably to contact via email first. </cntinst></cntinfo></proccont><procdesc>County, Township, and Section Summary Tables were created from larger Pesticide Use Reporting  PUR table (http://www.cdpr.ca.gov/docs/pur/purmain.htm) for cascading public land survey geographies on CoMTR (County-Meridian-Township-Range) and CoMTRS (County-Meridian-Township-Range-Section) by individual pesticide (and pesticide group, including group of all pesticides), by site (and site group, including group of all sites), by county (including all counties), and by year.  Listed below are steps for creating pesticide summary tables by county, township, and section:  1.  Checked with Pesticide Use Reporting (PUR) with most updated years (e.g.2008, 2009)  2.  Imported all counties and years into PUR table. Chemical code and site code have leading zeroes to 5 characters. The chemical code and site code can be found at California Department of Pesticide Regulation  http://www.cdpr.ca.gov/docs/label/labelque.htm  3.  Updated pesticide groups for (a) carcinogen status, (known, probable, and possible), (b) reproductive/developmental toxicants, (c) air toxins (EPA Hazardous Air Pollutant (HAP) or California Toxic Air Contaminant (TAC)), (d) endocrine disruption, and (e) cholinesterase inhibition to reflect Pesticide Action Network groupings (http://www.pesticideinfo.org/Search_Chemicals.jsp). The chem_code to be used for mappings in final table for (a)-(e) above are: (a) CARC, (b) DEV_REPRO, (c) AIR, (d) ENDO, and (e) ACHE respectively  4. Dissolved Public Land Survey layer on CoMTR (County-Meridian-Township-Range) from CoMTRS (County-Meridian-Township-Range-Section).  5.  Created 2 summary tables from larger pesticide application PUR table for 2 cascading public land survey geographies (CoMTRS, CoMTR), by individual pesticide (and pesticide group, including group of all pesticides), by site (and site group, including group of all sites), by county, and by year.  Both summary tables also have a chem_code column and the summary operator is "Group By".  The chem_code column includes individual chemicals as well as chemical groups specified by the mapping table "chemicals_to_groups".  A summary of all pesticides are included in both summary tables; The chem_code entry for all pesticides are "ALL".  Both summary tables have a primary key field.  Calculated a 3rd summary table for counties called udc_county_summary.  This table includes the following columns:  county_cd, applic_yr, chem_code, site_code, lbs_sum, applic_rate, acre_treated.  It also includes each of the chemical_groups and the "ALL" category for chem_code, each of the site_groups and the "ALL" category for site_code. NO applications with CoMTRS(County-Meridian-Township-Range-Section)=<null> are  included in any of these summary tables.  6.  Created 2 views that link feature classes in (4) to summary attribute tables in (5). The views have as many rows as the summary tables have; The summary tables in (5) are the primary tables and the feature classes in (4) are the foreign tables. The views have the following fields: pk, comtrs [or comtr], county_cd, applic_yr, lbs_sum, applic_rate, acre_treated, and shape. The "shape" field comes from the feature class in (4).  Here are the steps for creating township view as an example:  a.  Created udc_township_summary view that selects all records/fields from table udc_township_summary. b.  Create another view called pur_township_summary on udc_township_summary view and CoMTR feature class linking on the CoMTR field in a WHERE statement and including all the necessary fields. c.  Tested various permutations of SDE view in ArcMap.  Created a 3rd View called pur_county_view that joins a small scale county feature class with udc_county_summary table.  Created it similar to the other 2 views as in above steps a-c.  7.  Summary tables in (5) were summarized to characterize spread of values across CoMTRS and CoMTR for individual chem_code (including groups of chemicals and "ALL" category), site_code(including groups of sites and "ALL" category), by county (including all counties lumped together) and by year.  A custom percentile procedure was used in the summarization process to produce the 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles.  The resulting table "udc_percentiles" is used for categorization by the WMS at runtime.  Wrote a series of following SQL statements to create the "udc_percentiles" table:  a.  Created the udc_percentiles table with the indicated structure if it doesn't already exist b.  Created a loop that iterates the name of both of your summary tables (udc_township_summary and udc_section_summary) c.  Within (b) created loop through each of the chem_code in chemical table, site_code in site table, including group codes and the "ALL" category of all chemicals lumped together d.  Within (c) created loop through each of the checked years in study_years table (e.g. year 1991 - year 2009) e.  Within (d) created loop through each of the checked counties in study_counties table, including the "ALL" category of all counties lumped together f.  Within (e) created loop through each of the 3 possible pesticide summary metrics (lbs_sum, applic_rate, acres_treated) g.  Within (f) created loop through each of the possible percentiles (25, 50, 75, 90, 95, 99) h.  Within (g), for a given summary table (b), chem_code/site_code (c), year (d), county (e), metric (f), and percentile (g) calculated the percentile value by executing a stored procedure, i.  Inserted all the data gathered through steps (b) through (h) into table created in (a)  Summarized the udc_county_summary table to characterize the spread of values across county_cd's for individual chem_code and site_code.  Followed the same steps a-i noting that entries into udc_percentiles table have county_cd='ALL' and geography='counties'.</procdesc><procsv>ArcGIS 9.2, ArcSDE 9.2, SQL Server 2000</procsv></procstep></lineage></dataqual></metadata>
